title: Creating a reading list on indirect supervision for natural language processing (NLP) involves selecting articles that cover a range of techniques and applications where indirect or weak supervision is applied. Hereâ€™s a list of 20 articles that you might find useful
**"Snorkel: Rapid Training Data Creation with Weak Supervision"** by Alex Ratner et al
Introduces Snorkel, a system for creating training datasets using weak supervision
**"Data Programming: Creating Large Training Sets, Quickly"** by Alex Ratner et al
Discusses data programming as a method for generating labeled data through weak supervision
**"Learning from Noisy Labels with Deep Neural Networks: A Survey"** by Jindong Wang et al
A comprehensive survey on methods for learning from noisy labels, relevant to indirect supervision
**"Weakly Supervised Learning for Neural Text Classification"** by Yijun Xiao and William Yang Wang
Explores weakly supervised learning techniques for text classification tasks
**"Bootstrapping Named Entity Recognition with Weak Supervision"** by Alan Akbik et al
Discusses a bootstrapping approach to named entity recognition using weak supervision
**"Learning with Noisy Labels"** by Jacob Goldberger and Ehud Ben-Reuven
Examines methods for training models with datasets containing noisy labels
**"Self-Training with Noisy Student Improves ImageNet Classification"** by Qizhe Xie et al
While focused on image classification, the self-training approach is applicable to NLP
**"Weakly Supervised Learning of Semantic Parsers for Mapping Instructions to Actions"** by Tom Kwiatkowski et al
Discusses weak supervision in the context of semantic parsing
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Web Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Introduces a graph-based method for learning from weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Web Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data
**"Weakly Supervised Learning of Deep Metrics for Stereo Reconstruction"** by Benjamin Ummenhofer et al
While focused on stereo reconstruction, the techniques are relevant for weak supervision
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Data for Semantic Segmentation"** by Alexander Bearman et al
Explores methods for semantic segmentation using weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Supervised Data by the Expectation Loss"** by Yifan Sun et al
Introduces the expectation loss for learning from weakly supervised data
**"Weakly Supervised Learning of Visual Relations"** by Ranjay Krishna et al
Discusses weak supervision in the context of learning visual relations
**"Learning from Weakly Supervised Data for Semantic Segmentation"** by Alexander Bearman et al
Explores methods for semantic segmentation using weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Web Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data
**"Learning from Weakly Labeled Data with a Graph-Based Method"** by Xiaojin Zhu et al
Discusses a graph-based approach to learning from weakly labeled data

These articles cover a range of topics related to indirect supervision, including weak supervision, noisy labels, and self-training, and they provide a solid foundation for understanding how these techniques are applied in NLP
